text: very much Michael and thank you all for coming and delighted to see so many of you here but about myself I'm a curator
as michael has suggested and I work in the Victoria and Albert Museum in London and I sit in a quite recently
established department called design architecture and digital now we've been in post 3 years which in kind of Silicon
Valley terms is quite a long time but in museum terms in an institution that has over 160 years history we are still very
new we're just scratching the surface it's my first time in Stamford and I'm
really happy to be able to share some of the work that we are doing with you so

most frustrating games and the anger that it brought about was very much what

the fries that you see here kind of encapsulate that radical moment this is

charismatic first director put it more succinctly it was to be the powerful

having a look and improving your lot the vmas foundation I think you can term it
in it as a place to help navigate the anxieties of what was brought about by

this this usefulness this radicality is something that I and my colleagues in
the design architecture and digital department very much motivated by so since being in post in early 2013 we
have as a team of curators being tasked with looking at the design world of fresh and rapid response collecting was
our first act of this kind of radicality if you want to put it in those terms it's a new strand the museum's wider
collecting activity we are an institution with 3.5 million plus objects some of which are more than
7,000 years old so you have to understand that rapid response is one of its activities as the name suggests it's
simply about getting the thing itself into the museum quickly this may seem
obvious but museums as I've already in some ways suggested do move quite slowly
but it's also about thinking what the museum is for and what public institutions do in wider civic
infrastructure but also in the world in which we live and learn all the objects
that we acquire to our mind are objects that are part of public discourse and by
bringing the object itself into the museum and it is at this point in time so often a physical object but not only
and I think every object that I'm talking about today is a digital object but we can come on to that in the
questions and conversation afterwards and so we think we can deepen understanding by showing the thing
itself at this point I'd like you to understand that it's quite a modest project rapid response there are five
showcases and 12 objects on display at any one time and when we got our gallery
we were delighted we have about eight miles of galleries in the museum and our space is one that leads to another but
it was our own it's quite a modest budget which meant lining a set of cases
in metal and buying a printer to print our own magnetic labels this means that
we can get objects on display in days or weeks instead of months or years all that is the ambition so rapid response
opened to the public in July 2014 and the response has ranged from the
indifferent to the outraged em to the
sensational of course I like this almost but ultimately rapid response is about
placing questions of our relationships to new objects and new technologies in the public realm and so let's come on to
a number of the objects that we've acquired and I start with the firearm because it's already featured in a
number of the slides that we've been looking at so on the fifth of may 2013 Cody
successfully fired the first entirely 3d printed firearm many this couldn't be
done a moment celebrate for its maker
but could this plastic firearm have grave implications for gun control around the world so there is the
question it was released online for free this 3d file and the State Department
had forced or requested that Cody take it down within days and it was very
available on piratebay how we source our objects is one question that we might come too but then within within weeks we
sent one of our colleagues off to see Cody in his studio to secure objects for
the museum and I think while I'm talking about it think about this object in digital terms it's of interest because
it is a multiple and that you can create it at the press of the button but here we are as museum curators flying across
the pond to try and get the physical thing that said we it secured the object
with Cody and it was really one of our very first acts of rapid response collecting and frustratingly it was not
so rapid in the end because it took more than a year to get the object into the
UK and on display in the museum so here you have it being shipped as fine art and arriving in October 2014 and the
reason for this was that the export of this firearm necessitated a change in US
law because a plastic firearm fell without the legal frameworks of governance at the time of export and I
think if you think about these objects in those terms that is absolutely part and parcel of its interest for us and in
the wider context we as curators immediately thought that this was a
fundamentally important piece of contemporary design history in having
that physical thing in the museum we can both show its design brilliance in terms of it being a fantastically engineered
piece of work but also its absolute an immediate failure fire it three times and it
breaks if you want a proper gun there are other ways to go about it for Cody this was a political act for us in terms
of rapid response it's an object that has forever changed our understanding of distributed manufacturing it's about
regulation and the law and new depth on new technologies and how they have broad
ramifications it was one that blew the techno utopianism around 3d printing out
of the water and I think we are still experiencing the consequences of this and I don't think that's an
overstatement for this object Rapid Response objects as a whole are
important and interesting to us because they are material evidence physical evidence at the moment of social
political economic and technical change they are newsworthy and I think that's
part of what rapid responses success has been generated by but they are much more
so about showing advances in design but also objects that can reveal truths
about how we live together today another one of the objects that I'd like to
consider as a digital object but also to focus in on is a set of two painted umbrellas so sitting in London we were I
in particular observed the political disk wire in hong kong in late-september
2014 I'm sure that most of you are many of you aware that tear gas was used to
counteract citizens of Hong Kong in the streets protesting for what they consider to be democratic law they very
rapidly became known as all this set of this protest became known as the umbrella revolution and for us this was
again a functional object we are a design institution and every object that we acquire first and foremost has to be
something of design but here we have a functional object that has taken on political meaning we asked a local
academic and contact of ours to help us find an umbrella
at the time king sent us images of tents tote bags and other objects or
accoutrements accessories that have been made from recycled umbrellas but we were
firm in our desire for an object and that was useful and it was a useful
object that had been invested with a deeper meaning it became a shield from tear gas as well as from rain so we saw
two of the painted umbrellas there were very many painting umbrellas but we managed to find two located or we I say
King managed to find them for us painted umbrellas at this recycling point that was run by students who were very very
prominent within these protests at the Occupy admiralty site and I rather liked
that picture because it really brings home the object that we now have in the collection i should say they were
painted with the symbol kang which means to support to protect or to persevere but some King on once having collected
these objects he started to look at them a little bit more closely and he's an inquisitive individual very much
interested in popular culture and has an anthropological bent so if you notice
you'll see a small screen printed guy holding an umbrella aloft and for King this was a lead and a number of days
later I received an email from from ye in a young advertising executive and I'm
just going to read a quote from the email the umbrella revolution started on a Sunday afternoon we were shocked by
the tear gas but the citizens were so angry they were not frightened and more
and more people rushed to the street the next morning I brainstormed with my friends we wanted to do something to
gain more support we saw the term umbrella revolution created by the Foreign Press to try and name this
protest movement we decided to design and produce umbrellas and shoot a short
video asking people from different countries to hold an umbrella to support us our objective was to gain more
international support hoping that in many that it may put more pressure on the government
so again and 20 of his friends and colleagues collected as many umbrellas as they could from local retailers
turned out around 500 and painted and printed them by hand by Tuesday so
within days they were ready to shoot the video and with the help of those in
Causeway Bay they filmed the umbrellas being held aloft to the shaft of true
universal suffrage
and at this point just to come back to you in and what he thought and I focused
quite a lot to come back to yin and his
email I focus quite a lot on his correspondence because for me this is an integral part of the object and our
